msIdentifier.collection: John Frederick Lewis Collection of European Manuscripts

msContents.summary: This high-quality Flemish Book of Hours, probably produced in Bruges around the turn of the sixteenth century, is written in a fine Northern Rotunda script. It contains nine full-page miniatures attributed to the Master of Edward IV (active in Bruges between about 1470 and 1500), each of which is on the verso side of an inserted folio, facing the first page of the relevant text. Miniatures and their facing incipit pages are surrounded by lavish strewn-flower borders typical of the so-called Ghent-Bruges school. The flowers are painted in a naturalistic manner over a thin gold-wash ground, which is frequently inhabited by moths, birds, flies, and occasional zoomorphic or anthropomorphic creatures. The book's calendar is followed by the prayer to the Face of Christ, the "Salve sancta facies," introduced by an image of the Salvator Mundi along whose neckline the words "DOMINUS. DOMINUS" are discernable (fol. 16v). In a manner typical of Flemish Books of Hours, the Hours of the Cross and Hours of the Holy Spirit, as well as the Mass of the Virgin, precede the Hours of the Virgin; these sections are introduced by miniatures of the Crucifixion (fol. 18v), Pentecost (fol. 23v), and Virgin and Child (fol. 28v). The Hours of the Virgin itself contains miniatures of the Annunciation (fol. 35v) and Visitation (fol. 47v) for Matins and Lauds respectively, but no miniatures for the subsequent hours, which follow seamlessly without page breaks. The Penitential Psalms occur next, introduced by a miniature of the penitent King David (fol. 78v). The Office of the Dead begins with a miniature showing the Raising of Lazarus (fol. 91v). The final section, opening with an image of the Agony in the Garden (fol. 116v), contains readings from the Passion according to the four Evangelists. The upper and lower pastedowns of the book are original ruled blank pages, and are integral to the book block.

supportDesc.extent: 153; 215 x 145 mm bound to 227 x 162 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Modern foliation in pencil, upper right recto

p.catchwords: Original downward-facing catchwords in lower right margin at fols.: 36v; 44v; 53v; 61v; 69v; 86v; 95v; 103v; 111v; 120v; 128v; 136v; and 144v

layoutDesc.layout: One column of nineteen lines, ruled in red ink; written area: 112 x 79 mm

decoDesc.decoNote: Nine full-page miniatures with full inhabited floral borders; red, blue, and gold decorated initials and line fillers throughout
16vFull strewn-flower panel border with owl, bee, moth, and drollery
17rFull strewn-flower panel border with angel playing bagpipe, moths, fly, and monkey
18vFull strewn-flower panel border with bird, fly, moth, and drollery
19rFull strewn-flower panel border with moths and hooded man playing a citole
23vFull strewn-flower panel border shell, fly, and drollery
24rFull strewn-flower panel border with moths and anthropomorphic cock drollery
28vFull-page miniature, Virgin and Child with Musical Angels
28vFull strewn-flower panel border with bird and moths
29rFull strewn-flower panel border with moths, snail, and musical angel
35vFull strewn-flower panel border with moth and anthropomorphic peacock
36rFull strewn-flower panel border with moth, fly, and woman making a chaplet
47vFull strewn-flower panel border with moth and birds
48rFull strewn-flower panel border with moth, snail, musical man and griffin
78vFull strewn-flower panel border with bird, snail, and peacock
79rFull strewn-flower panel border with moths, gardener, and organ-playing bear
91vFull strewn-flower panel border with moths, skulls, and bones

binding.p: Black stamped morocco over wooden boards, possibly sixteenth-century

origin.p: TELMA-Luxury Bound gives a date of circa 1515; circa 1490-1520

history.provenance: Susan B. Minns (sold at American Art Association, 2-3 May 1922, lot 420); John Frederick Lewis, Philadelphia; given by his widow, Anne Baker Lewis, to the Free Library of Philadelphia in 1936; catalogue entry with illustration tipped onto inside front cover; pencil "310" written in inside front cover
